articles.headline: Getting to Retirement With Minimal Financial Risk
articles.snippet: In light of JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar loss, a look at how individuals can manage risk in their own investments with trade-offs and moderation.
articles.abstract: In light of JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar loss, a look at how individuals can manage risk in their own investments with trade-offs and moderation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s giant trading loss began as an effort to manage the bank’s risks — a move that turned into something that now looks more like a speculative bet. But don’t think this is solely a big-bank problem. Even small investors can run into trouble discerning the fine line between hedging and risk taking.

articles.headline: Heading Into Talks With Iran, U.S. Sees Hopeful Signs
articles.snippet: As American negotiators prepare for nuclear talks next week in Baghdad, they say recent statements from Iran and pressure from sanctions have raised the chances of compromise.
articles.abstract: As American negotiators prepare for nuclear talks next week in Baghdad, they say recent statements from Iran and pressure from sanctions have raised the chances of compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American negotiators, heading into a crucial round of talks with Iran over its nuclear program next week in Baghdad, are allowing themselves a rare emotion after more than a decade of fruitless haggling with Tehran: hope.

articles.headline: Facebook Builds Network of Friends in Washington
articles.snippet: Over the last five years, Facebook employees have met with members of Congress and walked them through ways to best to use the Web site.
articles.abstract: Over the last five years, Facebook employees have met with members of Congress and walked them through ways to best to use the Web site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For nearly five years, Facebook has quietly and deftly befriended the nation’s top lawmakers by giving them a little tech support.

articles.headline: Earmark Puts $17,000 Pans on Army Craft
articles.snippet: At a time of fiscal austerity, critics are pointing to the cost of a helicopter part made by a company whose owners are donors to Representative Harold Rogers, a Kentucky Republican.
articles.abstract: At a time of fiscal austerity, critics are pointing to the cost of a helicopter part made by a company whose owners are donors to Representative Harold Rogers, a Kentucky Republican.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the 1980s, the military had its infamous $800 toilet seat. Today, it has a $17,000 drip pan.

articles.headline: Rising Greek Political Star, Foe of Austerity, Puts Europe on Edge
articles.snippet: The left-wing leader Alexis Tsipras, who pledges to repudiate Greece’s austerity-for-loans bailout deal, says the country’s problem is a European one, necessitating a European solution.
articles.abstract: The left-wing leader Alexis Tsipras, who pledges to repudiate Greece’s austerity-for-loans bailout deal, says the country’s problem is a European one, necessitating a European solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — At 37, and looking not a bit his years, Alexis Tsipras is clearly enjoying his moment. He vaulted to prominence less than two weeks ago, when his previously obscure left-wing party placed second in national elections with the promise of repudiating the loan agreement Greece’s previous leaders signed in February.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Dissident From China Arrives in U.S., Ending an Ordeal
articles.snippet: Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer whose escape from house arrest jolted relations between the United States and China, followed a hastily arranged flight with an open-air news conference in New York.
articles.abstract: Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer whose escape from house arrest jolted relations between the United States and China, followed a hastily arranged flight with an open-air news conference in New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chen Guangcheng, the blind legal advocate who recently sought refuge in the American Embassy in Beijing, arrived in the heart of Greenwich Village on Saturday, holding the kind of open-air news conference that he could have never imagined while under virtual house arrest in China.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan, Andrew Jacobs and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Is Insider Trading Part of the Fabric?
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been getting tougher on insider trading on Wall Street, but its potential target may be too wide.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been getting tougher on insider trading on Wall Street, but its potential target may be too wide.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN before the news was official, it filtered out — unofficially — to Wall Street.

articles.headline: Seeing Bailouts Through Rose-Colored Glasses
articles.snippet: A recent Treasury analysis paints a glowing picture of the eventual outcome of the 2008 financial rescues. But taxpayers deserve a better breakdown of the costs and benefits.
articles.abstract: A recent Treasury analysis paints a glowing picture of the eventual outcome of the 2008 financial rescues. But taxpayers deserve a better breakdown of the costs and benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan Chase has revived the idea of paring down banks that are too big to manage. That’s a good thing, if we ever hope to get off the boom-bust-bailout track.

articles.headline: Discord at Key JPMorgan Unit Is Faulted in Loss
articles.snippet: Trans-Atlantic tension in JPMorgan Chase’s chief investment office contributed to the unit’s giant losing trades, current and former bankers said.
articles.abstract: Trans-Atlantic tension in JPMorgan Chase’s chief investment office contributed to the unit’s giant losing trades, current and former bankers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since JPMorgan Chase disclosed a multibillion-dollar trading loss this month, the central mystery has been how a bank known for its skill at risk management could err so badly.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: World Leaders Urge Growth, Not Austerity
articles.snippet: Meeting at Camp David, leaders of the world’s richest countries banded together to press Germany to back more pro-growth policies to halt the deepening debt crisis in Europe.
articles.abstract: Meeting at Camp David, leaders of the world’s richest countries banded together to press Germany to back more pro-growth policies to halt the deepening debt crisis in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP DAVID, Md. — Leaders of the world’s richest countries banded together on Saturday to press Germany to back more pro-growth policies to halt the deepening debt crisis in Europe, as President Obama for the first time gained widespread support for his argument that Europe, and the United States by extension, cannot afford Chancellor Angela Merkel’s one-size-fits-all approach emphasizing austerity.

articles.headline: Romney’s Faith, Silent but Deep
articles.snippet: While Mitt Romney has said little about his Mormon faith on the campaign trail, people who know him well call it a huge influence on his conduct and worldview.
articles.abstract: While Mitt Romney has said little about his Mormon faith on the campaign trail, people who know him well call it a huge influence on his conduct and worldview.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELMONT, Mass. — When Mitt Romney embarked on his first political race in 1994, he also slipped into a humble new role in the Mormon congregation he once led. On Sunday mornings, he stood in the sunlit chapel here teaching Bible classes for adults.

articles.headline: Charting Obama’s Journey to a Shift on Afghanistan
articles.snippet: President Obama concluded in his first year that the Bush-era dream of remaking Afghanistan was a fantasy. The lessons he has learned there have shaped his presidency.
articles.abstract: President Obama concluded in his first year that the Bush-era dream of remaking Afghanistan was a fantasy. The lessons he has learned there have shaped his presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was just one brief exchange about Afghanistan with an aide late in 2009, but it suggests how President Obama’s thinking about what he once called “a war of necessity” began to radically change less than a year after he took up residency in the White House.

articles.headline: Supply Lines Cast Shadow at NATO Meeting on Afghan War
articles.snippet: A deal to reopen military supply routes through Pakistan to Afghanistan fell apart just as President Obama began talks on ending the NATO alliance’s combat role in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A deal to reopen military supply routes through Pakistan to Afghanistan fell apart just as President Obama began talks on ending the NATO alliance’s combat role in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — President Obama was struggling to balance the United States’ relationship with two crucial but difficult allies on Sunday, after a deal to reopen supply lines through Pakistan to Afghanistan fell apart just as Mr. Obama began talks on ending the NATO alliance’s combat role in the Afghan war.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Maturing as Publisher and Platform
articles.snippet: The Atavist, which helps produce multimedia storytelling for digital devices, has a content management system that has turned into a business opportunity.
articles.abstract: The Atavist, which helps produce multimedia storytelling for digital devices, has a content management system that has turned into a business opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like the setup for a very old, stale joke. Three guys walked into a bar in Brooklyn to complain about the state of journalism ... except by the time these guys were done chatting and plotting, they had come up with an actual business.

articles.headline: From a Facebook Founder Comes a Way to Streamline Work Flow
articles.snippet: Asana, created by a Facebook co-founder, Dustin Moskovitz, is a shared to-do list for a company looking to make managing tasks at work a little easier.
articles.abstract: Asana, created by a Facebook co-founder, Dustin Moskovitz, is a shared to-do list for a company looking to make managing tasks at work a little easier.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s success has spawned a multimillion-dollar boom in social networking. There are networks for photo-sharers, for children and for workers inside companies. Yammer and Jive, for instance, promise to energize employees and increase their productivity by enabling fast information sharing.

articles.headline: Clash of the Theme Parks
articles.snippet: Universal Studios, the theme park chain now controlled by Comcast, is rolling out new weapons in its battle against Walt Disney Parks and Resorts — and Disney is fortifying its defenses.
articles.abstract: Universal Studios, the theme park chain now controlled by Comcast, is rolling out new weapons in its battle against Walt Disney Parks and Resorts — and Disney is fortifying its defenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Pull down your lap bars: Universal Studios, the theme park chain now controlled by Comcast, is rolling out new weapons in its battle against Walt Disney Parks and Resorts — and Disney is fortifying its defenses.

articles.headline: More Men Enter Fields Dominated by Women
articles.snippet: As steady full-time jobs with benefits are increasingly elusive, more men are reaching for a chance at the American dream in female-dominated occupations.
articles.abstract: As steady full-time jobs with benefits are increasingly elusive, more men are reaching for a chance at the American dream in female-dominated occupations.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Wearing brick-red scrubs and chatting in Spanish, Miguel Alquicira settled a tiny girl into an adult-size dental chair and soothed her through a set of X-rays. Then he ushered the dentist, a woman, into the room and stayed on to serve as interpreter.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Deal Expands Chinese Influence on Hollywood
articles.snippet: The Wanda Group will buy AMC Entertainment, making the world’s largest theater group, the companies said.
articles.abstract: The Wanda Group will buy AMC Entertainment, making the world’s largest theater group, the companies said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate with extensive interests in the entertainment business, has agreed to acquire AMC Entertainment, North America’s second-largest movie theater owner, in a deal that is valued at $2.6 billion, including roughly $2 billion in assumed debt, the companies said Sunday.

articles.headline: ‘Super PACs’ Let Strategists Off the Leash
articles.snippet: The freedom and unlimited cash of outside groups have increased the influence of a growing number of consultants and operatives in both parties.
articles.abstract: The freedom and unlimited cash of outside groups have increased the influence of a growing number of consultants and operatives in both parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: The intensifying flood of uncapped donations to outside political groups is transforming not just campaigns but the entire business of politics.

articles.headline: Leader’s Fall in China Put Allies in Peril
articles.snippet: The fall of Bo Xilai from the Communist Party’s top echelons has shed light into how some of his closest allies became entwined in his fate.
articles.abstract: The fall of Bo Xilai from the Communist Party’s top echelons has shed light into how some of his closest allies became entwined in his fate.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHONGQING, China — Early this year, as a crisis unfolded in the chambers of power here, three men flew into this fog-wreathed riverside metropolis within a day or two of one another. They were members of the inner court of Bo Xilai, the Communist Party aristocrat who ran the city, and they had come to repair a rupture between the strong-willed Mr. Bo and his equally driven police chief.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Qaeda Link Seen in Deadly Blast in Yemen Capital
articles.snippet: A huge suicide bombing on Monday stunned the beleaguered government and delivered a stark setback to the American campaign against Al Qaeda’s regional franchise.
articles.abstract: A huge suicide bombing on Monday stunned the beleaguered government and delivered a stark setback to the American campaign against Al Qaeda’s regional franchise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A huge suicide bombing in the heart of Yemen’s capital Monday morning left hundreds dead and wounded, stunning the country’s beleaguered government and delivering a stark setback to the American counterterrorism campaign against Al Qaeda’s regional franchise, which has repeatedly tried to plant bombs on United States-bound jetliners.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Europe Weighs Antitrust Case Against Google, Urging Search Changes
articles.snippet: The European Commission warned Google to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or possibly face an antitrust lawsuit.
articles.abstract: The European Commission warned Google to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or possibly face an antitrust lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Google may have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of competitors, the European Commission said Monday. It warned the company to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or possibly face an antitrust lawsuit.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and David Streitfeld
